titleInfo.title: Parade and arch honoring the "heroes of the Republican party and the first Cuban President"

mods.abstract: Sepia toned photograph, mounted on board, of a parade and triumphal arch on a street lined by buildings. Crowds of people stand under the arch on the buildings. Written on the arch: "Honor a los heroes el partido republicano al primer presidente [indeciperable]."

From 1898 to 1902, in the aftermath of the Spanish-American War, the United States Military occupied Cuba. The period is known as the First Occupation of Cuba. The 1901 Constitution of the Republic of Cuba was adopted with the Platt Amendment, which stipulated eight conditions for the withdrawal of U.S. troops and the protection of Cuba's independence from foreign intervention. On December 31, 1901, Tom√°s Estrada Palma (1835-1908) was elected as the first President of the Republic of Cuba. Palma resigned on September 28, 1906, leaving Cuba without a leader and opening the door for the Second Occupation of Cuba (Cuban Pacification), which lasted until 1909. A third occupation, the Sugar Intervention, lasted from 1917 to 1922.
